author: @hanneseckmayr8336
text:
Listening to this conversation, I can’t help but feel a deep sense of sadness and also disappointment. It’s almost painful to witness how blatantly Kenyans are being lied to by Mr. Ichung’wah.

Having lived in Kenya for almost five years, I’ve seen firsthand how deeply corruption is entrenched in nearly every aspect of daily life. It’s a reality that every Kenyan knows all too well. I always called it the “country of middlemen” because, in truth, the moment someone gains even the slightest bit of power, the temptation to exploit it often overwhelming.

From police officers fabricating offenses to extort bribes, to the absolute chaos at Nyayo House, where obtaining a visa or permit can take years unless you’re willing to pay the premiums —corruption isn’t just an issue in Kenya, it’s the system itself.

How can people be expected to trust in institutions when the political establishment lies so brazenly to its own citizens?

In my opinion trust cannot exist in a system where integrity is an illusion and power is merely a gateway to self-enrichment.

author: @ceciliakamau6457
text:
We can’t wait for this five-year term to end. The economy is in shambles now more than ever, and affording a meal has become a struggle under this government. It’s hard to point out a single positive achievement—just oppression and hardship.
As a Kenyan earning less than KSh 25,000, my heart aches. I can’t even begin to imagine what it’s like for those who are jobless or unable to afford a meal. We’re merely surviving; calling it "living" would be an overstatement.
Meanwhile, our so-called "hustler" president has donated millions to a church—not that supporting the church is wrong, but it’s an institution that is already well-off. His priorities and governance approach are deeply questionable. Civil servants are going home without pay due to a lack of funds, yet that money could have significantly impacted places like Turkana and other underprivileged areas. But because we want to be seen as "God-chosen" and righteous, we direct funds to the church instead of addressing urgent national needs. Smh.

author: @Wamzzzie
text:
Kimani Ichung'wah's performance was not particularly convincing. He came across as evasive, defensive, and unwilling to take responsibility for the shortcomings of the current government. His reliance on deflecting blame and downplaying serious issues likely reinforced negative perceptions of the government.
Lack of Direct Answers:He repeatedly avoided giving straight answers, particularly regarding the fulfillment of specific promises from the election manifesto. This damaged his credibility, as the interviewer pointed out.
Defensiveness and Evasiveness:He often deflected criticism by attacking the source of the information (e.g., Mehdi, Human Rights Watch) rather than directly addressing the substance of the claims.
Downplaying Serious Issues:He appeared to downplay the severity of issues like police brutality and abductions, using phrases like "lives had to be lost" and suggesting some abduction claims were fabricated. This came across as insensitive and out of touch.
Reliance on "Claims" Narrative:He frequently used the word "claims" to describe allegations of state-sponsored violence and disappearances, creating the impression that he was unwilling to acknowledge the possibility of government wrongdoing.
Blaming the Opposition/Previous Government:He often attributed problems to the previous administration or political opponents, which can be seen as a way to avoid taking responsibility for the current government's actions.
Contradictory Statements:There were instances where his statements seemed inconsistent, such as initially saying he would not give a straight answer and then claiming to have the answer.

author: @Wamzzzie
text:
Analysis of this interview: Ichungwa's Attitude Towards Ordinary Kenyans:
Out of Touch:His downplaying of issues like police brutality, abductions, and the cost of living suggests a potential disconnect from the everyday struggles of ordinary Kenyans.
Dismissive of Concerns:His tendency to attribute criticism to political opponents or "perception" could be interpreted as a dismissal of the genuine concerns of ordinary Kenyans.
Patronizing:At times, his responses come across as patronizing, as if he believes ordinary Kenyans are easily misled or don't understand the complexities of governing.
Tone-Deaf:While he highlights the government's efforts to improve the economy, he doesn't seem to fully grasp the public's skepticism and frustration, suggesting a potential lack of empathy.

author: @Nerry-G
text:
As a Nigerian who's country has gone through all these and still battling it now, I can say that this Majority Leader doesn't know what they are doing to their country yet.
He was DEFLECTING and DENYING every clearly incriminating question presented to him with facts as if they were trivial issues made up as stories just to evade answering them, and he thinks himself a smart wise star. But I assure you that sonner or later, him and his descendants will start to reap from the Kenya they helped to destroy.

In terms of corruption, they're taking their country to a place of decay that will be very difficult for it to recover from because the next set of House members will only take their established corruption norms to a higher level.
Kenyans need a real outsider who is a selfless savior to save them. Kenya is fast becoming a police state where the authorities are more keen in stifling and shutting down any loud critique than catering for the masses.

If they're not corrupt, let them show it by cutting down on their salaries - it's called Public Service and should not be about REWARD or HUGE SALARIES.
The House Members should also stop collecting money for Constituent Projects and stop being directly involved with major government Contract Allocation unless they're vetting, reviewing or scrutinizing a contract in conjunction with a reputatble external organization like pricewaterhousecoopers, etc.
These are their looting means.

author: @tilmanmai
text:
I was at the Nane Nane march just peacefully holding a sign: " Ruto - Tusikilize" (Ruto - listen to us) - I was arrested, jailed with approx. 100 other demonstrators - who were brutally beaten up by the prison guards while I was questioned (as a white "foreigner" [born in Kenya, but raised in Europe] - as to why I think I should have the right to demonstrate in a so-called democracy - by just showing support for the people under an oppressive government). Thirty hours later I was deported and blacklisted- to make sure I would not be able to return to Kenya.
The police is corrupt through and through as is the judiciary - so who in his right mind honestly believes, that police officers are goi g to be held accountable for any kind of crime in Kenya?

author: @SirMarita
text: Absolutely stunned by this interview! Mehdi Hasan did an incredible job asking the tough, critical questions that too many journalists here in Kenya fear to ask. The way he tackled the cost-of-living crisis, the finance bill, and the government’s harsh response to protests was both eye-opening and long overdue. As a Kenyan, it’s exhausting to watch our leaders dodge accountability, but this kind of bold journalism gives me real hope for change. Huge kudos to Al Jazeera for shining a light on these issues and holding power to account. Please keep delivering fearless reporting like this—we need it now more than ever!

This stark contrast exposes not just individual hesitation but a system that thrives on silencing truth through fear.

Adding to the kenyan health system is in shambles...SHA is not working,you pay a 1000 per month and the most it can do for you is pay Ksh 75 only for outpatient consultation in public hospitals. Lab tests, pharmacy and other services you have to pay cash,what kind of health insurance is that..?
Universal health coverage staffs have also been in employment from year 2020 earning a consolidated salary of only ksh50'000 after taxation it goes down to 39000,not permanent and pensionable as their colleagues who earn thrice their salaries,no allowances,no gratuity just job group stagnation,they can't even get banks loans while politicians get millions,The Kenyan nation is sick.

text: I have always said as an outsider Kenyans have a problem with two things. Lying and “saving face”. They are too comfortable with these negative traits. I watched this through gritted teeth in hopes one day beautiful Kenya will reach its potential. The religion and politics is killing that country, more than the money and greed. Money and greed is evidently evil in all its forms. Religion and politics is always disguised as public service, when it is anything but. Thoughts and prayers with the Kenyans struggling and those living honest lives ✌️ remember it’s not ok to lie. Being truthful always makes the best communities.

author: @josephjade5142
text:
On the question asked by the lady in the audience about police officers taking bribes. Being a Kenyan, I think the issue of bribes is a culture problem. We focus too much on the officers taking the bribes (not saying they shouldn't be punished for that); however, go to the streets and ask or observe any Kenyan caught on the wrong side of the law ,, or needs to have something or a process they need expedited, they themselves will end up asking whoever is in charge how much they want for them to let them go or expedite things for them by helping jump the queue ; or exploit the fact that whoever is in charge knows them.
That culture is not in enforcement officers alone,, but also in the bigger portion of ordinary 'Mwananchi' (Kenyan). Unless we the individuals change ,, the system won't either.

author: @widen.m
text: The Ruto regime has just messed us as Kenyans. They believe in retrogressive policies and Kenyans are suffering than before. We were headed to an almost universal working health coverage for all people. Linda mama for expectant moms, UPI for pupils and students, Aon insurance for civil and public servants and Nhif for general public were all working and very effective. Right now they have all been scraped with a confusing and ineffective Shif Sha corrupt scheme and people are really suffering and dying in hospitals yet payslip deductions for the same has doubled😢😢. May thunder strike this corrupt governance and may their families never find peace. Abductions, sufferings, injustices, punitive policies such as overtaxations and failed systems is the order of the day. Nothing to be proud of this pigs-led insensitive government

author: @phillipbanksvideo
text: In Kenya, I travelled from Nairobi to Masai Mara, and our truck was stopped and the driver had to pay the police. The amount was small, a few dollars. The driver had been spotted using his mobile phone. I told him that in Australia the fine for such use of the phone would be in the 400-500 range, not 2-3 dollars. On balance I think Australia is more corrupt than Kenya. The government take far more in Australia from you for minor misdemeanours than they do in Kenya. And as for the Politican being rich, with 1,000,000,000 Kenyan Shilling. That only equates to about $11 million AUD. Peter Dutton is allegedly worth $230 million AUD and he isn't even PM yet. Australian politicians seems to come into very nice jobs, with millions in pensions and benefits. On balance I am inclined to believe that Kenya was a very well structured growing developing nation with a healthy futire. Whereas Australia is an over inflated, expensive and bueracratically corrupt country, where taxing, fining, and over legilslating amounts to far worse consequencies than those mentioned in Kenya.

author: @phillipbanksvideo
text: Poor interview. The interviewer seemed almost apopleptic and continually interrupted the guest. It did nothing for the viewer. If anything it threw sympathy on the guest. The range of questions was limited and did not paint a wide enough view of the topic, in order to offer light on it. Sadly it reflects on the interviewer, that he came with a predisposition to berate his guest with. He might ask himself what is the point of inviting a guest, if you are not allowing them to reply unhindered. A good interviewer might have allowed the guest to speak more, then suggested that they offer their opinion as to why they believe what they do. Instead this interviewer continued a remorseless tirade of opinion. Last year I was in Nairobi during the riots. Most taxi and Uber drivers stated that they were neither concerned or surprised at the demonstrations, and that they were a symptom of a large body of youth, who had no jobs. To understand the police treatment would have been a more useful line of questioning, than to draw the guest into a polarized denial of government culpability. Kilmani was gracious and atttempted to answer. Guest 8/10 Interviewer 2/10.

And, btw, police cortiption was the first kind of corruption which was shoved in my face when I first came to Kenya!

author: @omusuguzakayo8548
text:
As a frustrated Kenyan, I want to voice my deep anger about the current state of our nation. The issues of police brutality, corruption, and the widening gap between the rich and the poor are painfully true and resonate with so many of us who have been directly affected by this regime.

We are tired!

Police Brutality: The violent crackdowns on peaceful protests and the tragic loss of lives are unacceptable. We are citizens demanding our rights, not criminals! The police should protect us, not harm us.

Corruption: The rampant corruption in our government is suffocating. The promises made during the election campaign have turned into mere rhetoric while our leaders indulge in extravagant lifestyles. This disconnect between politicians and the suffering public is infuriating.

Loss of Hope: We have lost faith in this administration. Every day, we witness the erosion of our rights and freedoms, and it feels like our voices are falling on deaf ears. The government needs to be held accountable for its actions, and we demand transparency and justice!

We cannot continue to live in fear and despair. It’s time for change, and we will not rest until our voices are heard and our rights are restored.

Enough is enough!😥😥😥😥😥😥😥😥

author: @kennedyobiero5697
text:
As a Kenyan,
The Kenyan MP is a perfect representation of what ails Africa. Politics is a lucrative business. Lucrative than be a teacher, an inventor, a scientist, etc. You have politicians saying casually how they are billionaires without any known business (product or service they offer) to their name. It is just tenderpreneurship and we import things, we don't create or manufacture. Secondly, it is the Ruto presidency that commits these crimes. However, Kenyans are to be blamed for what is happening in Kenya. For the last three election cycles, they have voted for two ICC criminals and the current president even campaigned against the new, progressive constitution. What did they expect? The ICC criminals are not free because they were found innocent but because witnesses disappeared, showed up dead, or were put in fear. In fact, as they were electing the crooks, they rejected Pro CHANGE forces. Lastly, his regime did not campaign on the platform of getting rid of corruption. That should have been an eye opener to Kenyans. His regime had a lot of corrupt individuals, including the president who has been mentioned in several corruption cases.

author: @Mbare-ui4tz
text:
Ichung'wah is more focused on political maneuvering than on genuine solutions to Kenya’s economic and social challenges. His approach alienates critics instead of engaging them, and his public accusations, whether against fellow politicians or the judiciary, only add to the instability.

At a time when the country needs honest dialogue and collective action, this kind of leadership risks deepening the cracks rather than building the bridges Kenyans desperately need.

author: @godfreykalumi6654
text:
First, at the beginning of the interview you say that you don't know who does the abductions and it's under investigation. At the end of the interview you are agreeing that it's the former deputy president. You're not saying the truth.

Second, corruption in Kenya is soo deep and you don't want to agree to that. Infact you're saying that the giver is on the wrong that's why police ask for bribe. Indirectly you are accepting the Police are corrupt. Police choose to harass the person on the wrong to get the bribe instead of following the proper disciplinary steps.

Unfortunately I have been involved in corruption and I had done nothing wrong. I attended my driving classes for more than a month. In my mind I didn't want to pay for it which some people do even without attending any driving class. During the final exam I passed the theory part and was to go for the practical. Upon reaching to the vehicle to be used for the practicals I was told they've lost my file and they can't find it. Spent whole day tracing it without success. Finally I was told if I pay they can look for it well. Got my license without doing the practical exam. Sooo bad and can't imagine it had to end thay way.

author: @pootymike2925
text: Kimani Ichung’wah’s interview was a shameless display of cowardice and dishonesty. Instead of confronting Kenya’s crippling corruption, police brutality, and economic decay, he hid behind excuses, shifting blame like a cornered thief. His pathetic attempts to downplay state-sanctioned murders were disgusting—how do you dismiss police brutality when bodies keep piling up? This wasn’t an interview; it was a masterclass in lying with a straight face while millions of Kenyans suffer under failed leadership. If incompetence had a spokesperson, it would be him.

author: @duntech
text: Kimani Ichung’wah’s dismissive stance on human rights violations and government accountability is deeply concerning. Denying documented cases of enforced disappearances and unlawful detentions only reinforces the perception that the government is unwilling to address its failures. Evasive responses about the administration’s progress on campaign promises further expose a lack of transparency and commitment to real change. If the government truly values democracy, it must stop deflecting criticism and start addressing the genuine concerns of its people.

author: @HarounRisaTheOneAndOnly
text:
Kimani Ichungwa thought Al-Jazeera was another Royal Media... He got the surprise of his life, aki.
He stammered and almost left the interview, especially after Mehdi Hassan told him that 95 percent of their promises had not been implemented (and Ichungwa kept stammering).

Then there was the part where Mehdi quoted Human Rights Watch. Ichungwa asked, "You'd rather believe what Human Rights Watch says than what I'm saying?" and Mehdi fearlessly replied, "Yeah."

That was amazing, Mehdi.

Asante sana, Mehdi Hassan. This is what journalism should be in Kenya.

author: @ExcitedChefHat-ef5jt
text:
Recent reports indicate a significant increase in human rights violations in Kenya under President William Ruto's administration. Human rights organizations have documented numerous cases of extrajudicial killings, enforced disappearances, and police brutality, particularly during anti-government protests.

In 2023, Human Rights Watch reported that Kenyan police committed grave rights abuses during protests, including excessive use of force and unlawful killings. Amnesty International also noted that at least 57 protesters were killed by authorities attempting to suppress dissent.

The Kenya National Commission on Human Rights (KNCHR) expressed concerns over the rising cost of living and its impact on economic and social rights, highlighting that President Ruto's pledge to reduce living costs within his first 100 days remained unfulfilled.

author: @aembewe
text: Democracy is not in the African DNA. The African DNA has a history of kingdoms and chiefdoms, absolute monarchies. We still have a lot of first generation African leaders in power today. Who opposes kings? Who dares to challenge a chief's decision? This is a case of Africa inheriting colonial governance systems and putting new wine into old wineskins. As Africans, we have a tough decision to make - either the old guard gives way to new leaders or we just go back to what our ancestors used to do.

author: @GoldDiamondJewelsGDJ-mu9hn
text:
In Kenya under Ruto, there are no meaningful charges, no arrests, no prosecutions, no probes, no reviews, no audits, no fact finding reports, cases are dropped at the president's request so for those reasons it is wrong to say that there hasn't been any major scandals in Kenya under Ruto because there are no credible investigations, the investigative agencies like the DCI, NIS are covering up crimes, misconduct and corruption.

If there were credible, transparent, open investigations then you can say that there hasn't been any big scandals under Ruto. If the investigative agencies were competent and independent then they would have opened a case against the president when Mr.Muturi said that the president made a phone call to the head of DCI then his son was released after that phone call because the president should have sacked the head of the DCI for holding someone without due process but the president did not do what a competent administrator would have done. Also if the investigative agencies were competent and independent then they would have already opened a case against the president for the recent allegations of Gold smuggling from Sudan through Kenya. And if the investigative agencies were independent and competent then there would have been an investigation to the allegations that Murkomen was caught in Dubai with billions in cash, Ruto flew to Dubai to negotiate for his release and flew back with him, to date there has never been any investigations and worse the opposition is pretending that it doesn't know about this allegation. So far no investigations, so you can see why there are no major scandals under Ruto. The NIS, DCI and the Interior ministry are part of the big cover-up.

author: @EnochGitongaKimathi
text:
I don't agree with the majority of the comments here. I think he answered the questions well as a politician.
When we talk about corruption, we just have to look at what President Donald Trump and Elon Musk are unearthing about corruption in America. Look at USAID. Few had the perception that America was corrupt in such levels. People thought USAID was a corruption free organisation.
Kenyans make trends but we also love following trends.
I live in Kenya, I'm self employed. When Kenyans say the economy is bad they are mostly not being honest. I look around where I live in Ngong I don't see poverty increasing.
Kenyans like breaking the law and getting away by paying bribes.
There is a lot of fake news in Kenya 🇰🇪

author: @paulerick6001
text:
William Ruto was Education Minister and Agriculture Minister under President Kibaki, the best economically performing leader in Kenya's short 60 year history, yet Ruto has no legacy worth mentioning from those terms in office! He claims and brands himself as having "inherited" a decrepit economy from the 10 year administration of Uhuru Kenyatta, with his Deputy Presidency! The two were like peas in a pod, courtesy the ICC trials. Now he claims he was ostracized during the 2d term and is therefore an outsider! LIES 🤥!!!
UHURU groomed him for the Presidency!!!
He claims he was cut out of government by a "handshake" between Uhuru and Raila Odinga! LIES 🤥!!! RUTO and Raila were partners in crime in 2007! That is why there was bloodshed, because Uhuru Kenyatta was there enemy!!! To prove these men are all lying, Ruto was back in bed politically with Raila in 2024 pushing for his AU chairperson candidature, and they have now signed a secret pact together!
So what is Ruto lying about "inheriting" a decrepit country. He is core to the problems the country is facing - and has been for at least 12 YEARS, IF NOT 20 years!!

author: @EmmanuelMotelin
text: No African leader is perfect, at-least Kenya doesn’t have a bad track record like the British empire and various other European atrocities globally. My president 🇰🇪 and our Kalenjin leader Ruto is here to stay until 2032. We as common sense Kenyans are confident in his leadership. We get that some Kikuyus (Not all of them) who are from Congo disagree. Many of who have been causing problems. I mean look at the situation in DRC with a lack of leadership. Our EAC chairman continues to make efforts to bring solutions even beyond borders. We also don’t expect to solve Haiti’s decades old problems but we answered their cry for help when many ignored them. No country is perfect. We sure also don’t tolerate threat actors who undermine security.

author: @djriggs8725
text:
Ichung'wa may not want to say it, but there was a coup in Kenya. He was trying to be diplomatic but he came off as cheesy and dubious. Oh Ichung'wa was a complete DISASTER. Terrible prep, terrible optics, terrible safe politics, terrible answers. He should go hide in the toilet till we call his name. Horrible performance!!! And I say this as a fan.

For the first time I will say Mehdi got his math wrong. My guy Mehdi never gets it wrong. but this one he... umm... he missed. I understand why he missed it so badly. Kenya's situation is a bit bizarre. It's operating backwards. Usually the govt is the presumed bad guy. Ordinarily. But in Kenya those civil society groups are the predators and the govt is the one trying to stop them from hunting and exploiting Kenyans. They formed systems of exploiting Kenyans and their status quo is getting disturbed. Let me substantiate to lend some credibility.

Do you know in Kenya only 10% of the population can get a mortgage? 90% can beg and wail all they want, no bank will ever ever ever ever give them a mortgage facility. The only way people can ever own a house is if they inherit then the whole family splits up the land or they just rent till the day they will save enough to build with cash. Pesident Ruto decided instead of forcing banks to give people mortgages, he would build houses and people can buy at just a THIRD of the market rate. Buying houses in the market demands 70% upfront and the balance within THREE months. But Ruto's houses you just pay 10% then pay whayever rent you can till the balance is cleared and the house is yours. No interest rate. Sounds good, right? Those Civil Society groups have been fighting it in court. They oppose 1.5% levy. What the heck is 1.5% surely? If I save that all my life it can't buy me a house. But if we pool it with the govt we can get a house even tomorrow morning. Yeah, they will fight it.



They fight Univesal Healthcare too (same story as Obamacare). Most Kenyans have ZERO healthcare insurance. None at all. Most have never known such a thing even exists. People are one illness from poverty. You fall ill. vultures are there to buy your livestock, land and property at throw away prices. The previous healthcare system had just 9 million subscribers, mainly paycheck people - in a country where 80% are informal sector, ie. no loans, no mortgages, no credit facilities and no paychecks. Ruto has a new people-crafted system (yes the people designed it - we can discuss that later) that caters to EVERYONE, formal sector, informal, jobless, bums everyone is covered. Despite all the attempts to block it in court or badmouth it with social media propaganda, the new system has almost TRIPLE the subscribers of the old system.

These fellows even oppose needy children being given meals in school for Ksh 5 ($0.04). Those you trusted as the voice of the people are usually just that. But in Kenya we have some weird backwards thing and they are actually the vultures. The only legit person there was Irungu Haughton. The rest nobody even knows who the heck they are. Mehdi Mehdi Mehdi. Welcome to the Kenyan Experience. Boy did you get it wrong. Next time be more alert.

And Ichung'wa sucked big time. BOO that guy.

author: @KeahKidambi
text:
As a country, lies have eaten us up like a cancer. The problem with telling lies so often is that at some point, even the liar genuinely can't tell the difference between his lies and the truth. Now, the worst part of being a narcissistic and pathological liar is that people often read you like a song book. They can, from a far, always see how the lies are conjured and concocted bit by bit and all they have to do is to simply pull off a single string and the web of lies crambles on its own weight.
Many thanks to Mehdi for doing the Lord's work. Much love from Kenya.

text: In all honesty, it is time Kenyans stop being angry and start taking responsibility of our own actions especially when it comes to exercising our civil rights. author: @ericnjogu8527
text:
26:29 You asked for it. In recent years, both President William Samoei Ruto and National Assembly Majority Leader Kimani Ichung’wah have been implicated in several corruption scandals that have raised significant concerns about their leadership and commitment to good governance in Kenya.

1. William Ruto's Corruption Scandals

Kenya Medical Supplies Authority (KEMSA) Scandal: In 2023, the KEMSA was embroiled in a scandal involving the mismanagement of Ksh. 3.7 billion allocated for the procurement of mosquito nets. Allegations pointed to irregular tender awards and inflated prices, leading to public outcry and demands for accountability within President Ruto's administration.
NTV KENYA

Taxation and Governance Issues: President Ruto's tenure has been marked by widespread protests over high taxation and perceived poor governance. In response to these protests, he dismissed nearly all of his Cabinet ministers in February 2025, promising to form a leaner and more efficient government. This move was seen by many as an attempt to quell public dissent and address the corruption allegations plaguing his administration.
STAR TRIBUNE

Dismissal of High-Profile Cases: There have been instances where corruption cases involving close associates of President Ruto, amounting to approximately KSh 30 billion, have been withdrawn or dismissed. This pattern raises questions about the administration's dedication to combating graft within its ranks.

2. Kimani Ichung’wah's Corruption Allegations

Kitisuru Falls Residence Project: Majority Leader Kimani Ichung’wah has faced allegations regarding the rapid construction of a luxurious apartment complex known as the Kitisuru Falls Residence. Critics, including blogger and activist Francis Gaitho, have questioned the source of funding for this project, suggesting it may be linked to corrupt activities. The six towering 14-floor apartments reportedly sprang up in record time, raising suspicions about their financing and construction processes.

Wealth Accumulation: In a recent interview, Ichung’wah disclosed his net worth to be close to Ksh. 1 billion, attributing his wealth to various business ventures and prior employment before his political career. This revelation has sparked debates about the correlation between his political position and his substantial wealth, with some questioning the legitimacy of his financial gains.


These cases highlight the pressing need for transparency and accountability within Kenya's leadership. The allegations against both President Ruto and Majority Leader Ichung’wah underscore the challenges the nation faces in combating corruption and restoring public trust in its institutions.

Sources:

author: @ZubeidaAli-g4r
text:
The KK government is a walking contradiction in all aspects of their governance or so to say "lack of". Picking solely from the discussions, MP ichungwah constantly refers to these abductions as "allegations". However, in the same breath the president of Kenya and HIS party leader spoke publicly in December and said "What has been said about abductions, we will stop them so Kenyan youth can live in peace, but they should have discipline and be polite so that we can build Kenya together,” This in itself is a blatant admission that these ARE in fact state sanctioned abductions. So who are Kenyans meant to believe from the two???? We have seen the Kenyan ministry of foreign affairs take part in forceful repatriation THROUGH abductions of the 4 turkish nationals who were in fact seeking asylum in Kenya from the Erdoğan administration. The abduction of Uganda's Kizza Besigye that was ENABLED by the Kenyan National Intelligence Service. The attempted abduction of Tanzanian activist, Maria Sarungi. And the list goes on.
If we have institutions in place that are supposedly working well, why is the Kenyan government months later STILL unable to show the Kenyan people WITH EVIDENCE who are behind these abductions? It took them a couple of days to supposedly identify who the serial killer behind the kware murders were but when it comes to issues such as abductions and extra judicial killings is where they draw the line? Kimani please!!!!
I wish there would be a part 2 of this interview with this said individual where we could continue to talk about all things failing in this state in terms of institutions i.e education, health, political elitism, corruption/ misappropriation of our taxes and even talk about the criminal elites running this fraudulent government! There is clearly ALOT more to say and to unpack and hold the Kenyan political class to account for!

author: @realallano110
text: When someone sarcastically says "nice red bottom shoes," they're likely poking fun at the idea of flaunting luxury or status. "Red bottoms" typically refer to Christian Louboutin shoes, famous for their signature red soles and hefty price tag. The sarcasm could imply that the shoes—or the person wearing them—are trying too hard to impress, or that the expense is ridiculous for something as simple as footwear. It’s a backhanded compliment, like saying, "Oh, great, you’ve got expensive taste—good for you," with an eye roll baked in. Context matters, though—who’s saying it and why could shift the vibe from playful to shady.

author: @mgg-l90
text:
Kimani Ichung'wah’s responses were overwhelmingly avoidant, prioritizing defense of Ruto’s administration over substantive engagement with Kenya’s crises. Key themes:

Denialism: Rejected evidence of state violence/corruption.

Elitism: Dismissed public anger over wealth inequality.

Gaslighting: Framed victims/activists as liars or political tools.

Accountability Failure: Reliance on rhetoric, not institutional action.

Final Rating: 2/5 (Avoidant on critical issues; minimal transparency).

author: @mrben8886
text: I love this Mehdi. As Kenyan Genzs, we need to see a change!  The perennial cycle of egregious corruption, gross mismanagement, and flagrant impunity in Kenya’s governance is both infuriating and disheartening. Year after year, we are inundated with scandals, grand theft of public resources, and empty rhetoric from leaders who feign concern while perpetuating systemic rot. Infrastructure crumbles, essential services deteriorate, and the common citizen is left to languish in economic despair. Yet, the architects of this dysfunction remain untouchable, shielded by a broken system that rewards incompetence and deceit. How much longer must we endure this blatant betrayal? When will leadership cease to be a self-enrichment scheme and instead serve its true purpose—uplifting the people? We need to see a  better Kenya!

author: @bonaogeto
text:
"I Feel Sorry for My Country"

I feel sorry for my country,
Where truth is drowned in power’s lies,
Where justice fades like evening light,
And hope is met with weary sighs.

You stand in halls of marble bright,
Defending thieves with crafted speech,
While mothers weep, their children starve,
Their cries too distant for you to reach.

You cloak oppression with empty words,
Call tyranny by softer names,
Yet streets are red with shattered dreams,
And ash still smolders from your flames.

You raise your voice in bold defense,
Of broken trusts and stolen bread,
Yet when the people call for change,
You greet them with a rain of lead.

One day, the walls will shake and fall,
The echoes of the past will call,
And history will write your name,
Not in honor, but in shame.

I feel sorry for my country,
Not because we are weak or lost,
But because those who swore to serve,
Sold our souls, and named the cost.

author: @panafrican.nation
text:
I have followed Mehdi Hasan for 2 decades. I'm a fan of this Oxford University alumnus. So glad he's addressing our plight as Kenyans.

If you're facing Mehdi, you better come prepared. For he will be prepared. He will quote your own words verbatim, readily. I remember his interview with Raila Odinga in 2008.

The sheer work he must put in per interview must be massive. We're in sync on so many issues including Palestine.

Edit: Just noticed that Mehdi spells his last name as Hasan with a single 's'. I don't like getting people's names wrong.

author: @UNILINKNEXUSINTERNATIONAL
text:
Ruto is corrupt ;
1. THE MAIZE SCANDAL IN THE GRAND COALITION GOVERNMENT
The scandal broke out in 2009. At the time, William Ruto was the Minister for Agriculture in the Grand Coalition government.

2. HUSTLER’ JET SCANDAL
This scandal took place in May 2013, a month after the Jubilee Government took power.
Deputy President William Ruto allegedly hired a private jet for KES 100 million for his ‘shuttled diplomacy’ in West Africa. The trip was to lobby West African countries to support their cause at the International Criminal Court.

3. LANG’ATA PRIMARY SCHOOL LAND GRAB
William Ruto’s name featured prominently in the scandal. Some ‘faceless’ developers tried to grab the Lang’ata Primary School playground in 2015. He initially denied owning the Weston Hotel, which attempted to convert the playground to a parking lot.
The police responded ruthlessly and tear-gassed innocent schoolchildren. The aftermath was public outcry locally and around the world on how the police handled the protest.

4. THE KENYA PIPELINE LAND SCAM
William Ruto and four other persons faced fraud charges in court. The charges involved the alleged sale of a piece of land in Ngong forest to Kenya Pipeline Company Ltd for Sh272 million. The accusers argued that Ruto and his cohorts acquired and sold the land illegally.

5. MOI TEACHING AND REFERRAL HOSPITAL (MTRH) SCANDAL
A Nairobi businessperson linked Ruto to a controversial KES 28 billion deal. The businessperson, Hebert Ojwang’, said the deal was to put up a new referral hospital in Eldoret.
